ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learnt more about Econometric methods and public health

Writing a senior essay can be a really difficult thing. It forces you to stop solving problems that you are assigned on a problem set, and faces you to actually think about a question to tackle. It is a really different intellectual exercise than most of the work I have done at Yale up to now.
I hadn't done economics research before this at Yale, so I've learned a lot about writing economics papers, doing the research, and staying accountable to an independent project with few deadlines.
Gained experience working on an empirical project.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The research portion was very exciting, and the many resources provided by the department were very helpful.
You can decide what you eat to work on yourself, and it helps you to get to know a professor much better.

The TA's and Professor Toseland are so helpful and resourceful! I think this just comes with doing independent research but I didn't know I had to do a lot of emailing/networking for my data needs and I wish I had known this earlier. I hope this helps someone.

Strengths: Super awesome experience to write an economics thesis, especially with Rebecca and Matthew at the helm. A lot of clear communication and flexibility compared with other people writing theses in other departments. Never really felt stressed about deadlines, and there's a huge amount of support for students to get connected with professors and find the correct resources for their projects. Pretty world-class experience.

Weaknesses: We had a deadline in mid November for our paper (just an update to our advisor) but I'm not really sure what the purpose was of that. I feel like it could be nice to have something published online that tells us where we should be roughly at different stages of the writing process (I also acknowledge that everyone has different timelines, so this could be tough). I think it was just tough for me to gauge my progress relative to where I "should be."

The experience of doing independent research has been great so far. The weekly lectures were useful for the most part, although it might have been nice to cover slightly more advanced material since we've all had an introduction to R in prior courses.
A strength is that the weekly lectures are recorded and Professor Toseland is very engaging.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it is a meaningful capstone to the Economics major.

I only reckoned it if you have enthusiasm for tackling a question of your own making, or a professor's question that interests you. If you are just taking it to check off a box, I think you will have a very tough time.

Yes -- I didn't initially know if I wanted to write a thesis (and I hadn't done Tobin or Scarf, so I felt a little behind relative to peers in terms of experience). But it's totally something that any economics major can do (just make sure you have enough econometrics) and a hugely fulfilling experience. It's special to work on an independent project like this one, and I've learned more in this thesis-writing process than in most of my other economics classes at Yale.
I'd definitely recommend writing a senior essay, as it's a great experience.
